concepts.name: Ma'at
concepts.shortDescription: The fundamental concept of truth, justice, balance, order, and cosmic harmony in ancient Egyptian philosophy
concepts.longDescription: Ma'at is the foundational principle of truth, justice, balance, order, harmony, law, morality, and cosmic order in ancient Egyptian thought. More than just a goddess, ma'at represents the ordered structure of reality itself, established by Ra at creation to replace the chaos of Nun. Ma'at exists in eternal opposition to isfet (chaos, disorder, falsehood, injustice).

relatedConcepts.name: Dharma
relatedConcepts.relationship: parallel - cosmic law and moral order

concepts.culturalSignificance: Ma'at provided the ethical framework for Egyptian society and the pharaoh's primary duty was to maintain ma'at. In the afterlife, the heart was weighed against Ma'at's feather to determine worthiness for eternal life.
practices: Acting with justice toward all people
Pharaoh offering Ma'at figurines to gods
Judges called 'Priests of Ma'at' upholding truth

etymology.derivation: From the root mÍú£ ø meaning 'straight, true'

concepts.name: Karma
concepts.shortDescription: The universal principle that all intentional actions have consequences that determine future conditions across lifetimes
concepts.longDescription: Karma is the law of cause and effect governing moral actions and their consequences. Every intentional action creates karmic residue that affects future experiences, either in this life or future rebirths. In Buddhism and Hinduism, karma drives the cycle of rebirth (samsara) and can only be transcended through enlightenment.

relatedConcepts.name: Dharma
relatedConcepts.relationship: complementary - dharma guides right action to create good karma

relatedConcepts.name: Ma'at
relatedConcepts.relationship: parallel - cosmic justice and moral order

concepts.culturalSignificance: Karma provides moral framework explaining suffering and inequality as consequences of past actions, while offering hope through the possibility of improving one's situation through right action.
practices: Mindful action with awareness of consequences
Charity and compassion to improve karma

etymology.derivation: From root k·πõ meaning 'to do, to make'

concepts.name: Dharma
concepts.shortDescription: The cosmic law, moral order, and righteous duty that upholds the universe and guides proper conduct
concepts.longDescription: Dharma is a multifaceted concept encompassing cosmic law, moral order, religious duty, and righteous conduct. It represents both the universal principles that uphold reality and the specific duties appropriate to one's station in life (varna-dharma). Living according to dharma maintains cosmic order and generates positive karma.

relatedConcepts.name: Ma'at
relatedConcepts.relationship: parallel - cosmic order and moral law

relatedConcepts.name: Dao
relatedConcepts.relationship: parallel - the way of cosmic harmony

concepts.culturalSignificance: Dharma forms the foundation of Hindu ethics and social organization, defining duties for different life stages and social classes. The concept of protecting and upholding dharma justifies divine incarnations (avatars).

etymology.derivation: From root dh·πõ meaning 'to hold, to sustain'

concepts.name: Dao (Tao)
concepts.shortDescription: The fundamental way or path underlying all existence, the source and pattern of the universe in Chinese philosophy
concepts.longDescription: The Dao is the ultimate reality, the source and pattern of all existence. It is both the origin of the universe and the natural way things should proceed. The Dao cannot be fully defined or named, as it transcends human concepts. Living in harmony with the Dao (wu wei - effortless action) is the highest wisdom.

relatedConcepts.name: Qi
relatedConcepts.relationship: manifestation - vital energy flowing from Dao

relatedConcepts.name: Wu Wei
relatedConcepts.relationship: practice - effortless action aligned with Dao

relatedConcepts.name: Dharma
relatedConcepts.relationship: parallel - cosmic order and natural law

personifications.name: Laozi
personifications.description: Legendary sage who taught the Dao

concepts.culturalSignificance: The Dao is the central concept of Daoism and profoundly influences Chinese philosophy, religion, art, and culture. It emphasizes naturalness, spontaneity, and harmony with the cosmos.

etymology.derivation: Pictograph combining 'head' and 'walking', suggesting a path or way

concepts.name: Wyrd
concepts.shortDescription: The complex concept of fate, destiny, and the web of cause and effect woven by actions in Norse belief
concepts.longDescription: Wyrd represents fate not as predetermined destiny but as the accumulated consequence of past actions creating present circumstances. The Norns weave wyrd at the base of Yggdrasil, representing how past deeds shape future possibilities. Unlike fatalism, wyrd acknowledges personal agency while recognizing the weight of the past.

personifications.name: The Norns
personifications.description: Three beings who weave wyrd at Yggdrasil's roots

concepts.culturalSignificance: Wyrd shaped Norse understanding of heroism and honor. Since fate could not be escaped, what mattered was how one faced it. This belief fostered courage and acceptance of death in battle.
practices: Maintaining family honor to shape descendants' wyrd

alternativeNames.name: Weird
alternativeNames.meaning: Originally meant fate, now means strange

etymology.derivation: From *wurdiz, related to *wer√æanƒÖ (to become)

concepts.name: Nirvana
concepts.shortDescription: The ultimate state of liberation from suffering, desire, and the cycle of rebirth; the extinction of greed, hatred, and delusion
concepts.longDescription: Nirvana (literally 'extinguishing' or 'blowing out') is the ultimate goal of Buddhist practice, representing complete liberation from suffering (dukkha), desire, and the cycle of rebirth (samsara). It is the extinction of the three poisons: greed, hatred, and delusion. Nirvana transcends conceptual description, being beyond existence and non-existence.

opposites.name: Samsara
opposites.relationship: cosmic opposite - liberation vs. cyclic existence

concepts.culturalSignificance: Nirvana represents the supreme goal of Buddhist spiritual practice, the end of all suffering. It motivates monastic renunciation and meditation practice across Buddhist traditions.

etymology.derivation: From nir- (out) + vƒÅ (to blow)

concepts.name: Yin-Yang
concepts.shortDescription: The fundamental complementary opposites whose dynamic interplay generates all phenomena in Chinese cosmology
concepts.longDescription: Yin and Yang are the two fundamental, complementary forces that constitute all existence. Yin represents the feminine, receptive, dark, cool, passive principle, while Yang represents the masculine, active, bright, warm, dynamic principle. They are not opposites in conflict but interdependent forces whose interaction creates balance and generates all phenomena. Each contains the seed of the other, and they continuously transform into each other.

relatedConcepts.name: Dao
relatedConcepts.relationship: source - Dao gives rise to yin-yang

relatedConcepts.name: Qi
relatedConcepts.relationship: manifestation - qi has yin and yang aspects

concepts.culturalSignificance: Yin-Yang theory profoundly influences Chinese medicine, martial arts, feng shui, divination (I Ching), and understanding of natural and social phenomena as dynamic balances rather than static states.
practices: Seasonal living aligned with yin-yang cycles

etymology.meaning: Yin: shady side of hill; Yang: sunny side of hill
etymology.derivation: Originally referred to the shaded and sunlit sides of a mountain

concepts.name: Hubris
concepts.shortDescription: Excessive pride, arrogance, and defiance of the gods that inevitably leads to downfall in Greek thought
concepts.longDescription: Hubris is excessive pride, arrogance, and presumption, especially toward the gods. It represents the human impulse to overstep proper bounds and claim more honor than one deserves. In Greek tragedy and mythology, hubris inevitably provokes divine retribution (nemesis), leading to the transgressor's downfall. Hubris violates the proper order and hierarchy of the cosmos.

personifications.name: Nemesis
personifications.description: Goddess of retribution who punishes hubris

concepts.culturalSignificance: Hubris is central to Greek tragedy, where heroes' excessive pride leads to catastrophic downfall. The concept reinforced social norms about knowing one's place and respecting divine power.
practices: Making offerings to avoid divine wrath

etymology.derivation: Originally meant violent assault, later extended to arrogant pride

concepts.name: Arete
concepts.shortDescription: Excellence and virtue of any kind; the realization of one's full potential and purpose
concepts.longDescription: Arete represents excellence, virtue, and the fulfillment of purpose or function. For Homer, it meant martial prowess and heroic excellence. For philosophers, it expanded to include moral and intellectual virtues. Arete is context-dependent: a knife's arete is sharpness, a horse's is speed, and a human's is excellence of character and mind.
concepts.culturalSignificance: Arete was central to Greek paideia (education) and formed the basis of Greek ethics. The pursuit of excellence drove Greek competitive culture in athletics, arts, warfare, and philosophy.

etymology.derivation: Possibly from *ar-is-ta (best), related to √°ristos (best)

concepts.name: Xenia
concepts.shortDescription: Sacred hospitality and the reciprocal relationship between host and guest protected by Zeus Xenios
concepts.longDescription: Xenia is the sacred law of hospitality that governed the relationship between hosts and guests in ancient Greece. Protected by Zeus Xenios, xenia required hosts to provide food, shelter, and protection to guests, while guests must respect the host's household and not overstay. Violations of xenia brought divine punishment. The relationship created lasting bonds between families.

personifications.name: Zeus Xenios
personifications.description: Zeus as protector of guests and hospitality

concepts.culturalSignificance: Xenia was fundamental to Greek social order, enabling travel and trade in a world without hotels. Breaking xenia could justify wars (as in the Trojan War). The concept emphasized that strangers might be gods in disguise.
practices: Providing food and shelter to guests
Exchanging gifts between host and guest
Not harming those under one's roof

etymology.derivation: From x√©nos (stranger, guest, host)

concepts.name: Nemesis
concepts.shortDescription: Divine retribution and righteous indignation against those who succumb to hubris or gain undeserved good fortune
concepts.longDescription: Nemesis represents divine retribution, righteous indignation, and the restoration of cosmic balance. It is the force that punishes hubris, arrogance, and excessive good fortune. Nemesis ensures that no one rises too high or enjoys too much undeserved success, maintaining the proper order of things.
concepts.culturalSignificance: Nemesis reinforced Greek beliefs about moderation, humility, and the danger of excessive pride. It explained why the mighty fall and provided moral order to the universe.

etymology.meaning: distribution of what is due, retribution
etymology.derivation: From n√©m≈ç (to distribute, to dispense)

concepts.name: Moira
concepts.shortDescription: Fate, destiny, and one's allotted portion in life determined at birth by the Moirai (Fates)
concepts.longDescription: Moira represents fate, destiny, and the portion of life allotted to each person. The concept encompasses both individual destiny and cosmic order. While fate is determined, Greek thought also acknowledged human agency within those bounds. Even gods respect moira, as it represents fundamental cosmic law.

personifications.name: The Moirai (Fates)
personifications.description: Three goddesses who spin, measure, and cut the thread of life

concepts.culturalSignificance: Moira shaped Greek understanding of life's limitations and the importance of accepting one's lot. It explained suffering while allowing for heroic striving within fate's bounds.

etymology.derivation: From *mer- (to allot, to assign)

concepts.name: Moksha
concepts.shortDescription: Liberation from the cycle of birth, death, and rebirth; union with the ultimate reality (Brahman)
concepts.longDescription: Moksha is the ultimate goal of Hindu spiritual life, representing complete liberation from samsara (the cycle of rebirth). It is achieved through realizing one's true nature as Atman (soul) and its unity with Brahman (ultimate reality). Different paths lead to moksha: knowledge (jnana), devotion (bhakti), action (karma), and meditation (raja yoga).

opposites.name: Samsara
opposites.relationship: cosmic opposite - liberation vs. cyclic bondage

relatedConcepts.name: Brahman
relatedConcepts.relationship: ultimate reality united with in moksha

concepts.culturalSignificance: Moksha represents the highest human aspiration in Hindu thought, transcending worldly concerns. The four purusarthas (goals of life) culminate in moksha after dharma, artha, and kama.

etymology.derivation: From muc/mok·π£ (to free, to release)

concepts.name: Maya
concepts.shortDescription: The cosmic illusion or creative power that veils the true nature of reality (Brahman) from perception
concepts.longDescription: Maya is the power of illusion that makes the multiplicity of the phenomenal world appear real, veiling the singular truth of Brahman. In Advaita Vedanta, maya creates the appearance of separation between Atman and Brahman. Maya is not simply falsehood but the creative power through which the One appears as many. Enlightenment involves seeing through maya to recognize ultimate reality.
concepts.culturalSignificance: Maya explains why enlightened beings see unity while ordinary perception sees multiplicity. It provides philosophical framework for understanding illusion and reality in Hindu metaphysics.

etymology.derivation: From mƒÅ (to measure, to create)

concepts.name: Samsara
concepts.shortDescription: The endless cycle of birth, death, and rebirth driven by karma and from which liberation is sought
concepts.longDescription: Samsara is the continuous cycle of birth, death, and rebirth through which souls transmigrate based on their karma. It encompasses all realms of existence from hell to heaven. Samsara is characterized by dukkha (suffering/unsatisfactoriness) in Buddhist thought. The goal of spiritual practice is to escape samsara through moksha (Hinduism) or nirvana (Buddhism).
concepts.culturalSignificance: Samsara provides the cosmological framework for understanding life's suffering and the urgency of spiritual practice. It explains inequality and injustice as karmic consequences while offering hope through the possibility of liberation.

etymology.derivation: From sam (together) + s·πõ (to flow)

concepts.name: Qi (Chi)
concepts.shortDescription: The vital life force or energy that flows through all living things and the universe in Chinese philosophy
concepts.longDescription: Qi is the vital energy or life force that permeates all existence. It flows through the body via meridians, through the land via dragon lines, and through time via seasonal cycles. Health, both personal and cosmic, depends on the free and balanced flow of qi. Qi has yin and yang aspects and manifests in countless forms from subtle spiritual energy to solid matter.

relatedConcepts.name: Yin-Yang
relatedConcepts.relationship: qi has yin and yang aspects

concepts.culturalSignificance: Qi is fundamental to Chinese medicine, martial arts, feng shui, and understanding of health and vitality. Practices focus on cultivating, balancing, and directing qi for health and spiritual development.
practices: Feng shui to harmonize environmental qi

etymology.derivation: Pictograph showing rising vapor or breath

concepts.name: Wu Wei
concepts.shortDescription: Effortless action, non-forcing, or acting in accordance with the natural flow of the Dao
concepts.longDescription: Wu wei literally means 'non-action' or 'non-doing,' but it actually refers to effortless action in harmony with the natural flow of the Dao. It is action without forcing, striving without struggling, achieving without effort. Wu wei is like water flowing around obstacles rather than confronting them directly. It represents the highest skill and naturalness.

relatedConcepts.name: Dao
relatedConcepts.relationship: wu wei aligns with the Dao

concepts.culturalSignificance: Wu wei is central to Daoist philosophy and practice, influencing Chinese attitudes toward governance, art, martial arts, and daily life. It teaches working with natural forces rather than against them.
practices: Martial arts flowing with opponent's energy

etymology.derivation: w√∫ (without, not) + w√©i (action, doing)

concepts.name: De (Te)
concepts.shortDescription: Virtue, power, or moral force that naturally emanates from alignment with the Dao
concepts.longDescription: De represents virtue, inner power, and the natural potency that comes from alignment with the Dao. It is not moral virtue in the Western sense but rather the intrinsic power and integrity of things being true to their nature. A ruler with de governs effortlessly; a sage with de influences without forcing. De is cultivated through wu wei and living according to the Dao.
concepts.culturalSignificance: De is the second key concept in the Dao De Jing (Classic of the Way and Virtue) and central to Daoist ethics. It influenced Confucian thought about moral cultivation and virtuous governance.

etymology.derivation: Originally meant to advance, go straight

concepts.name: Orlog
concepts.shortDescription: Primal law, fundamental order, and the accumulated layers of past actions underlying wyrd
concepts.longDescription: Orlog represents the primal layers of past actions and their consequences that establish the fundamental order of reality. It is the accumulated √∏rl√∂g (past layers) from which wyrd emerges. Orlog is both the cosmic law and the weight of all that has been done. While wyrd is dynamic and can be influenced, orlog represents the deep structure of fate established by primordial actions.

personifications.name: The Norns
personifications.description: Keepers of orlog at Yggdrasil's roots

concepts.culturalSignificance: Orlog provided the metaphysical foundation for Norse ethics, explaining how past actions create present conditions and future possibilities. It emphasized ancestral responsibility and honor.
practices: Building good orlog through worthy deeds

etymology.derivation: √∏r- (primal, ancient) + l√∂g (law, layers)

concepts.name: Hamingja
concepts.shortDescription: Personal luck, spiritual power, and guardian spirit that can be inherited and transferred in Norse belief
concepts.longDescription: Hamingja represents a person's luck, fortune, and spiritual power. It is both an abstract quality and sometimes personified as a guardian spirit (often appearing as an animal). Hamingja can be strong or weak, built through worthy deeds or diminished through shameful acts. It is transferable and inheritable, with powerful individuals having strong hamingja that could benefit their followers.
concepts.culturalSignificance: Hamingja explained differences in fortune and success. It motivated honorable conduct (which builds hamingja) and explained why following a powerful leader brought benefits (sharing their hamingja).
practices: Avoiding shameful acts that weaken hamingja

etymology.derivation: Related to hamr (shape, form) + gja (to give)

concepts.name: Dukkha
concepts.shortDescription: Suffering, unsatisfactoriness, and stress inherent in conditioned existence; the First Noble Truth of Buddhism
concepts.longDescription: Dukkha is the First Noble Truth of Buddhism, encompassing suffering, dissatisfaction, stress, and the inherently unsatisfactory nature of conditioned existence. It ranges from obvious suffering (pain, grief) to subtle unsatisfactoriness (impermanence, lack of ultimate satisfaction). Dukkha arises from attachment, aversion, and ignorance. Understanding dukkha motivates the Buddhist path.
concepts.culturalSignificance: Dukkha is the starting point of Buddhist teaching and practice. Recognizing dukkha motivates the search for liberation and distinguishes Buddhism's practical, psychological approach to suffering.
practices: Following Eightfold Path to end dukkha

etymology.derivation: dus (bad, difficult) + kha (space, axle hole) - originally 'bad axle hole' causing rough ride

concepts.name: Anicca
concepts.shortDescription: Impermanence; the universal characteristic that all conditioned phenomena are constantly changing
concepts.longDescription: Anicca is one of the Three Marks of Existence in Buddhism, representing the impermanence and constant change of all conditioned phenomena. Nothing in samsara is permanent, stable, or eternal - everything arises, changes, and passes away. Understanding anicca deeply leads to non-attachment and is essential for liberation.

relatedConcepts.name: Dukkha
relatedConcepts.relationship: suffering arising from attachment to impermanent things

concepts.culturalSignificance: Anicca meditation is central to Buddhist practice, fostering non-attachment and equanimity. Recognizing impermanence reduces suffering by preventing clinging to transient experiences.

etymology.derivation: an- (not) + icca/nitya (permanent, constant)

concepts.name: Anatta
concepts.shortDescription: No-self or non-self; the teaching that there is no permanent, unchanging self or soul
concepts.longDescription: Anatta is one of the Three Marks of Existence, teaching that there is no permanent, unchanging self, soul, or essence in any phenomenon. The apparent self is actually five aggregates (skandhas) in constant flux. This distinguishes Buddhism from Hinduism's atman doctrine. Realizing anatta is crucial for liberation, as the illusion of self causes attachment and suffering.

opposites.name: Atman
opposites.relationship: Hindu concept of permanent soul that Buddhism denies

relatedConcepts.name: Dukkha
relatedConcepts.relationship: suffering arising from clinging to illusory self

relatedConcepts.name: Sunyata
relatedConcepts.relationship: emptiness extending no-self to all phenomena

concepts.culturalSignificance: Anatta is Buddhism's most distinctive and radical teaching, setting it apart from other Indian religions. It revolutionizes understanding of identity, responsibility, and liberation.

etymology.derivation: an- (not) + attƒÅ/ƒÅtman (self, soul)

concepts.name: Nwyfre
concepts.shortDescription: The vital life force, spiritual energy, and sky power in Welsh Celtic cosmology
concepts.longDescription: Nwyfre (sky power) is the vital, creative life force that flows through all existence in Celtic cosmology. It is one of the three elements (with gwyar/fluidity and calas/solidity) composing reality. Nwyfre represents spirit, consciousness, and the animating principle. It connects to inspiration, awen, and the divine spark within all beings.
concepts.culturalSignificance: Nwyfre represents Celtic understanding of spiritual energy and consciousness permeating nature. It underlies Druidic practices and Celtic animism.

etymology.derivation: Related to nwyf (energy, passion) + bre (sky, heaven)

concepts.name: Geis (Geas)
concepts.shortDescription: A sacred prohibition, obligation, or supernatural injunction placed upon a person in Celtic tradition
concepts.longDescription: A geis (plural geasa) is a sacred taboo, prohibition, or obligation placed upon a person, often by magical or divine means. Breaking one's geis results in misfortune, loss of power, or death. Heroes often have multiple geasa that can create impossible dilemmas. Geasa shape destiny and test character, representing the binding power of words and sacred oaths.
concepts.culturalSignificance: Geasa feature prominently in Irish mythology, especially in tragic hero tales. They represent the binding power of oaths, the weight of destiny, and the complexity of honor.
texts: The Fate of the Children of Tuireann
The Destruction of Da Derga's Hostel

etymology.derivation: Possibly related to geis (swan) or proto-Celtic *westu- (command)

concepts.name: Sovereignty
concepts.shortDescription: The sacred connection between land, goddess, and rightful king in Celtic tradition
concepts.longDescription: Sovereignty in Celtic tradition is both a goddess and a principle representing the sacred marriage between king and land. The rightful king is chosen by the sovereignty goddess and must prove worthy. The king's fitness directly affects the land's fertility and prosperity. Breaking this sacred bond brings disaster. Sovereignty goddesses often appear as beautiful women or hags, transforming when the true king is found.

relatedConcepts.name: Geis
relatedConcepts.relationship: kings bound by geasa related to sovereignty

concepts.culturalSignificance: Sovereignty mythology legitimized kingship and explained the sacred connection between ruler and ruled land. It emphasized that kings served the land, not merely ruled it.
texts: The Adventures of the Sons of Eochaid Mugmed√≥n

etymology.derivation: From flaith (prince, chief, heavenly being)

concepts.name: Kami
concepts.shortDescription: Sacred spirits, divine essence, or spiritual presence in all things in Shinto belief
concepts.longDescription: Kami are the sacred spirits, divine beings, or numinous qualities that inhabit all things in Shinto. They are not gods in the Western sense but rather spiritual essences or powers. Kami can be natural phenomena (mountains, rivers, sun), ancestral spirits, or abstract qualities. Everything with exceptional or mysterious qualities possesses kami. Humans can become kami after death.

relatedConcepts.name: Musubi
relatedConcepts.relationship: creative and harmonizing power of kami

concepts.culturalSignificance: Kami are central to Shinto and Japanese culture, fostering reverence for nature, ancestors, and sacred places. The concept underlies Japanese animism and nature worship.

etymology.derivation: Etymology uncertain; possibly from kami (above) or kamu (to be fragrant/divine)

concepts.name: Musubi
concepts.shortDescription: The creative and harmonizing power of connection, binding, and bringing together in Shinto cosmology
concepts.longDescription: Musubi is the creative, generative, and harmonizing power in Shinto cosmology. It represents the power of birth, growth, connection, and bringing things together into harmonious relationship. Three primordial musubi kami embody this power: Takami-musubi, Kami-musubi, and Ame-no-minaka-nushi. Musubi is the force of life, creativity, and the bonds that unite all existence.
concepts.culturalSignificance: Musubi underlies Shinto understanding of creation, growth, and harmonious relationships. It influences Japanese emphasis on social bonds, connection, and harmony (wa).

etymology.derivation: From musu (to be born, to grow) + hi/bi (spirit, divine)

concepts.name: Kegare
concepts.shortDescription: Ritual impurity, pollution, or defilement that must be purified in Shinto practice
concepts.longDescription: Kegare is ritual impurity or pollution in Shinto belief. It arises from contact with death, blood, disease, or certain taboo violations. Kegare is not moral sin but a state of spiritual contamination that disrupts harmony with kami. It requires purification (harae/misogi) to restore purity (hare). Understanding kegare is essential to Shinto ritual practice.
concepts.culturalSignificance: Kegare shaped Japanese attitudes toward purity, cleanliness, and ritual. It influenced social organization and continues to affect Japanese cultural practices around purification.

etymology.derivation: From kegaru (to be defiled, to become impure)

concepts.name: Hare
concepts.shortDescription: Sacred purity, clarity, and the state of being spiritually clean and suitable for kami interaction
concepts.longDescription: Hare represents sacred purity, clarity, and the purified state appropriate for interaction with kami. It contrasts with kegare (impurity) and ke (ordinary daily life). Hare is the condition achieved through purification rituals and maintained during sacred times and spaces. Festivals (matsuri) are hare occasions when the sacred becomes manifest.

relatedConcepts.name: Ke
relatedConcepts.relationship: ordinary state between hare and kegare

concepts.culturalSignificance: Hare underlies Shinto emphasis on purity, cleanliness, and proper ritual state. It shapes Japanese aesthetics, architecture (clean lines), and cultural practices around purification.

etymology.derivation: From hareru (to clear up, to become pure)
